author: Mike Kelly
title: Brexit letter - petition demands government withdraw university information request
text:
Click to play Tap to play The video will start in 8 Cancel Play now Get daily   Thank you for subscribing!   
A petition signed by nearly 2,400 academics has been sent to the government demanding it make clear no university need provide details of what they are teaching their students about Brexit. 
Organised by Prof Thom Brooks, the Dean of Durham Law School, it follows a letter last month from Tory MP and whip Chris Heaton-Harris to all UK vice-chancellors which also asked for a list of lecturers who taught the subject. 
It sparked outrage and Prof Brooks revealed it has taken just one week to collect 2,390 names from all over the world which were sent on Thursday morning to universities minister Jo Johnson. Video Loading Click to play Tap to play The video will start in 8 Cancel Play now 
Prof Brooks said: “This isn’t a symbolic of one letter being countered by another letter. 
“While neither the Prime Minister nor her minister appear to support Heaton-Harris’s request, both have not made clear to universities they can disregard the letter if they wish. 
“We’re looking for the government to draw a line under it. 
“We have the highest standards set for teaching quality and these should not be cast aside in pursuit of a political agenda.” Read More Tory MP's Brexit letter - North East universities to ignore 'sinister' information request 
The original letter, written on House of Commons headed notepaper, generated alarm as many people thought it was threatening academic freedom. 
Universities were asked to produce lists of what teaching in European affairs relating to Brexit took place, the names of individual staff members teaching on EU matters and for links to lecture recordings. 
It was seen by some as ‘McCarthyite’ and ‘sinister’ in tone while Prof Brooks called it ‘dog whistle politics at its worst’. A letter by Chris Heaton-Harris to the University of Worcester (Image: University of Worcester / Conservative Party) 
And while all North East universities quickly refused to provide the information, that wasn’t the case around the country, according to the North East academic. 
Prof Brooks said that was why he organised the petition to Mr Johnson which calls on him to write to all vice-chancellors contacted by Mr Heaton-Harris to confirm that none are required to release the information requested. 
The petition reads: ‘In so doing, he would reaffirm his government’s commitment to academic freedom, debate and the high quality of teaching standards at our country’s higher education institutions’. 
It was claimed Mr Heaton-Harris wanted the information for research purposes - there was mention of a book - which led some people to say it was it was a storm in a tea cup. 
Prof Brooks didn’t agree. He said: “There’s a very strong right wing view in American that universities are ‘indoctrination factories’.” Read More 
Prof Brooks described the phenomenon as “culture wars” and added: “It’s said when the US sneezes the world catches a cold. I’m worried that the culture war is being transferred here.” 
We contacted for the Department for Education for comment. Like us on Facebook
